comments.body:
[~mmunn1], assuming this works to close the socket as expected on the web services side, there is a thing to check on that I'm not sure about off hand:  Does the {{Context}} get cleared for the {{Channel}}?

Specifically, on the web services side (not on the client side) there is extra state associated with each {{Channel}} opened that is kept in {{Contexts}}.  That state gets cleaned up on the {{ChannelStateEvent}} corresponding to the {{CLOSE}} of the channel (called from {{/com/eucalyptus/ws/server/ServiceContextHandler.java:190}}).

Is the {{e.getChannel().close()}} as called in the above snippet propagating that channel event up? (*it should!*)

To check this, there is a part I'm not sure how to do easily:
# The client has to send a valid request (so that the server creates the context)
# The request has to be a streaming upload request (so that the server doesn't close the socket after responding)
# The client has to sit there sending nothing for longer than the {{timeout}}
Maybe [~viglesias] knows? Possibly give a fifo file as input to {{s3tup}}?

Once there is a way to trigger this case, the question is whether there are extra {{Context}} objects piling up, which can be checked with:
{code}
 ~ 19004 > euca-modify-property -p euca='com.eucalyptus.context.Contexts.channelContexts'
PROPERTY	euca	{[id: 0x378ef0e7, /10.8.0.94:37702 => /10.111.1.45:8773]=com.eucalyptus.context.Context@4dae1943} was executed successfully.
{code}
This example shows only the {{Context}} object for that request there.

If we do see that happening (*shouldn't*), the remedy is to explicitly clear the {{Context}} in the {{idletimeout}} handler like in {{/com/eucalyptus/ws/server/ServiceContextHandler.java:223}}
